title: Blog Writing Anti-AI Framework
description: Guidelines to write blogs that avoid obvious AI patterns. This ensures authentic, human-friendly posts with real voice, natural flow, and credible insights.

guidelines.description: Don't force neat round numbers (1000, 1500 words). Let depth of insight, not token padding, drive length.
Skip long generic scene-setting. Limit intros to 1–2 paragraphs and get to substance quickly.
Avoid uniform 4–5 sentence paragraphs. Mix short one-liners with longer, more detailed sections.
Don't restate ideas three different ways to hit length. Make the point once and move forward.
Every ~200 words, use subheads, examples, quotes, or lists to keep the text skimmable.
Use quotes, data, or real references. Never hallucinate stats or expert names.
Avoid filler headings like 'The Future of X.' Make subheads descriptive and curiosity-driven.
Cut repetitive AI patterns like 'Top 10 Ways to…' or 'The Ultimate Guide.' Use titles with personality, context, or contrarian hooks.
Don't build perfectly symmetrical structures (intro → 3 bullets → conclusion). Mix pacing, break rhythm intentionally.
Avoid disembodied narration. Anchor sections in a viewpoint: lived pain, project learnings, or observed struggles.
Tie benefits to real frustrations (e.g. 'spending weekends editing spreadsheets'), not abstract 'time savings.'
No spammy CTAs throughout. Use one strong, value-driven CTA at the end, or a natural one mid-post.
Don't mix corporate jargon with casual slang. Pick a voice and stick with it.
Don't finish with vague 'the future is bright' inspiration. Conclude with sharp takeaways, steps, or earned opinions.
Don't always present ideas in neat triplets. Humans don't structure that rigidly.
Cut formulaic 'while X, Y' or 'although X, Y' constructions. Use plain, direct phrasing.
Ban phrases like 'in a world where' or 'in today's landscape.' They're AI tells.
Replace formulaic 'let's dive in' with contextual bridges.
Use commas, periods, or parentheses. Avoid dramatic em dash overuse.
Let fragments, side comments, or quirks through. Humans leave fingerprints.
Cut lines like 'In this article, we'll explore' or 'This post covers'. Start directly with the insight or story.
guidelines.example_bad: In this post, we'll explore how teams can boost productivity.
guidelines.example_good: Last quarter our team hit a wall — here's what fixed it.

guidelines.description: Avoid abstract moralizing ('a testament to resilience', 'underscores the importance of'). Replace with plain, concrete outcomes.
guidelines.example_bad: This project stands as a testament to teamwork.
guidelines.example_good: We shipped 12 fixes in a week because everyone pulled late nights.

guidelines.description: Don't hide behind phrases like 'experts agree' or 'research shows.' Cite real names or share firsthand data.
guidelines.example_good: Nielsen's 2023 report found narrative-driven ads held attention 40% longer.

guidelines.description: Skip empty range metaphors like 'from burnout to balance.' Use specific before-and-after data or experience.
guidelines.example_bad: From struggle to success, it was a wild ride.
guidelines.example_good: Six drafts later, the post finally hit 100k reads.

guidelines.description: Avoid 'Moreover', 'Furthermore', 'In conclusion', 'Overall.' End sections naturally or with a clear opinion.
guidelines.example_bad: In conclusion, creativity remains key to success.
guidelines.example_good: Creative work still wins — even when it's messy.

guidelines.description: Don't end with 'Thanks for reading' or moral lessons ('Stay curious!'). Let the last sentence carry the punch.
guidelines.example_bad: Thanks for reading — remember, persistence pays off!
guidelines.example_good: The real trick? Showing up even when you hate your own draft.

guidelines.description: Don't leave behind markdown symbols like ## or **bold** in plain-text exports. Keep formatting clean and minimal.

conclusion: Blogs should read like they come from a person, not a machine. That means natural pacing, varied structure, anchored insights, and credible references — with no self-referential intros, inflated phrasing, vague authority, or polite moral wrap-ups. Imperfection is a feature, not a bug.
